poem:
**Reformation in Englishtown**

Potatoes still sleep beneath earth,  
under clamor of dragsters  
and whispers of old battles.  
John Alite, balloon-tied,  
floats past shadows of his past,  
a councilman's pen replacing the gun—  
Englishtown leans in,  
a town of 2,350 souls,  
half-breath eager, half-breath cautious,  
listening to the rustle of plans.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Former mob killer leaves crime behind to become New Jersey councilman John Alite has big plans for Englishtown, New Jersey, a small hamlet best known for potatoes, a drag racing strip, and the Battle of Monmouth during the revolutionary wars. But not everyone is certain they want Alite, 62, having a say over municipal matters in the town of about 2,350 people, where he was appointed a council member earlier this year and comes up". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
